channel.title: Chatham House podcast content
channel.description: Chatham House, the Royal Institute of International Affairs, is an independent policy institute based in London. The institute is a world-leading source of independent analysis, informed debate and influential ideas on how to build a sustainably secure, prosperous and just world for all. This feed provides our latest podcast content
channel.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Undercurrents: Episode 1 - Cybersecurity and Liberal World Order
item.itunes:summary: In this new podcast series, Agnes Frimston and Ben Horton interview Chatham House experts about the critical underlying issues which are shaping modern society.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: America Under Trump
item.itunes:summary: At this event, the panel analyse the current administration and its national and international impact so far. What are the major challenges for Trump’s presidency and how best can the US prepare for them?
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: International Affairs Podcast: Banking Crises and Politics
item.itunes:summary: In the latest instalment of the International Affairs podcast, Ben Horton speaks to two recent authors about their research on the relationship between banking crises and political unrest.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Understanding Ignorance: The Fall of the Expert?
item.itunes:summary: In the internet age, where people can more readily fact-check or substantiate claims, why would expert opinion be shunned and what is taking its place?
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: The Creative Partnership of Humans and Technology
item.itunes:summary: Edward Lee discusses the possibilities for collaboration and the co-evolution of human and artificial intelligence.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: The Future of Global Health
item.itunes:summary: Drawing from the findings of the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine report Global Health and the Future Role of the United States, this event analyses future global health priorities.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: International Affairs Book Reviews Podcast: Tom Fletcher on Social Media and Diplomacy
item.itunes:summary: In the first in a new podcast series from International Affairs, former UK Ambassador to Lebanon Tom Fletcher, discusses his recent book The Naked Diplomat.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Kurdistan's Independence Referendum: The Beginning of Further Instability in the Region?
item.itunes:summary: Our panellists discuss the impact that the outcome of the referendum will have on the Kurdish population, Iraq and the wider Middle East.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Unfinished Business: The Unexplored Causes of the Financial Crisis
item.itunes:summary: Drawing on the findings from his new book, Tam Bayoumi outlines the cumulative policy errors on either side of the North Atlantic that he believes has undermined the stability of both the European and the US financial sectors.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: China’s Economy: Why Conventional Wisdom Can Be Wrong
item.itunes:summary: Yukon Huang, author of the new book Cracking the China Conundrum: Why Conventional Economic Wisdom Is Wrong, addresses changes in the Chinese economy.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Privacy, Encryption and Hacktivism: Is Your Information Safe Online?
item.itunes:summary: Our panel assess what confidentiality encryption security affords, the risks to people’s everyday privacy on the internet and whether associated threats are overblown.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Should Governments Be More Transparent About the Use of Drone Strikes?
item.itunes:summary: The panellists present ways in which governments can reduce the opaque nature of drone strikes while at the same time ensuring military and state interests are protected.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Chatham House Forum: Is The West Damaging Democracy?
item.itunes:summary: Brian Klaas presents the case that there is currently a perfect storm raging against democracy, which the West is directly facilitating.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: The Annual Russia Lecture: The Role of Energy Resources in Russia’s Future
item.itunes:summary: Professor Thane Gustafson, author of Wheel of Fortune: the Battle for Oil and Power in Russia, shares his views on Russia’s energy outlook and its impact on the rest of the country’s economy.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Helping Iraq’s Displaced Peoples Return Home
item.itunes:summary: The panel outline key findings drawn from the 2017 Windsor Conference, Religious Persecution – The Driver for Forced Migration.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: More Than War
item.itunes:summary: The head of the British Army discusses how land forces can help prevent conflict and promote wider British interests at a time of sharper international competition between nation states.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Screening Room: City of Ghosts
item.itunes:summary: City of Ghosts, directed by the Academy Award-nominated and Emmy award winner, Matthew Heineman, follows the movements of the anonymous Syrian activists group Raqqa Is Being Slaughtered Silently (RBSS).
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Internally Displaced People: The World’s Most Pressing Humanitarian Crisis?
item.itunes:summary: The panellists identify proposals to create successful synergies between global and local actors in order to urgently address this hidden humanitarian crisis.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Institutions of the State: Policymaking in the GCC
item.itunes:summary: Our panel analyse policymaking approaches in the GCC and the balance of power in the region.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Chatham House Primer: Algorithms
item.itunes:summary: Using analogies drawn from both daily life and familiar stories such as Hansel and Gretel, Back to the Future and Indiana Jones, Professor Martin Erwig explains a series of key concepts in computing.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Leaders Who Lunch: Michael Anderson on Successful Leadership
item.itunes:summary: The ‘Leaders who Lunch’ series gives Academy fellows the opportunity to discuss leadership experiences and lessons in an informal setting.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: International Affairs 93: 4 - Contentious Borders in the Middle East
item.itunes:summary: In this latest instalment of the International Affairs Podcast, guests discuss the contents of the July issue.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Japan and the World: Episode 7
item.itunes:summary: In this podcast, Céline Pajon sits down with John Nilsson-Wright to discuss the importance of so-called ‘gray zone situations’ in the East China Sea.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Chatham House Forum: Is Child Labour Always Wrong?
item.itunes:summary: Dorte Thorsen argues that, by outlawing child labour entirely, governments are ultimately harming the very people they are trying to protect.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Trump’s America: What Does the World Think?
item.itunes:summary: Following the election of President Donald Trump, how is the US perceived by the global public and how does this impact the country’s international relations?
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Iran’s New Role in the Middle East
item.itunes:summary: Dr Kamal Kharazi, the former Iranian minister of foreign affairs, reflects on Iran’s role in the Middle East following the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), agreed between the P5+1, the EU and Iran.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: What Happens if the UK Leaves the EU without a Deal?
item.itunes:summary: In the wake of the election result, our panellists discuss the likely legal, economic and political consequences of leaving the EU with no deal in place.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Cyber Populism: Is Social Media Damaging Democracy?
item.itunes:summary: The panel discusses the findings of a new report by the Oxford Internet Institute which examines how governments use social media to influence public opinion.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: The UAE View of the GCC Crisis: What Happened and What Happens Next?
item.itunes:summary: The Emirati minister of foreign affairs discusses his country’s current foreign policy aims and ambitions.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Screening Room: Drugs, Policing and Security in the West Bank
item.itunes:summary: In his latest documentary, Ross Kemp explores the growing epidemic of drug addiction wreaking terrible effects on Palestinian society in the West Bank.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Technology Against Terrorism: How to Respond to the Exploitation of the Internet
item.itunes:summary: This panel of distinguished speakers discuss the threat of the spread of extremism via technology.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Navigating a Post-Truth Age
item.itunes:summary: Drawing on behavioural science, economics, psychology and his first-hand experience of the media industry, Davis analyses how society has come to accept as normal post-truth discourse.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Recovering Africa's Stolen Assets: Lessons from the Windward Trading Case
item.itunes:summary: This event invites speakers from Kenya and Jersey to examine how lessons from the Windward case might be applied in other sub-Saharan African countries and in international corruption cases.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Chatham House Forum: Is Transparency Good for Democracy?
item.itunes:summary: Ivan Krastev challenges the idea that increasing transparency improves public trust in democracy, arguing that, in reality, knowing more about those who govern us means that mistrust becomes rife and democratic actions, such as voting, decrease.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: The Forgotten Jihadists: the Resurgence of Al Qaeda?
item.itunes:summary: Drawing on findings from their new book, award winning investigative journalists assess the resurgence of Al Qaeda in the Middle East in light of recent ISIS defeats.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: International Affairs 93:3 - Brazil's Rise, Russia and Ukraine
item.itunes:summary: In this latest instalment of the International Affairs podcast, guests discuss the contents of the May issue.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Are the Sustainable Development Goals more than Aspirations?
item.itunes:summary: The panellists analyse the strengths and weaknesses of the SDGs on the global stage.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Global Britain: How Can the UK Stay Relevant on the World Stage?
item.itunes:summary: The panellists explore the relevance to today’s Britain of the changing nature of the diplomatic service, the need for streamlined funding and the role of cultural institutions such as the BBC World Service.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: The Future of American Power
item.itunes:summary: Thomas Wright assesses why it is that a number of commentators are arguing that the liberal international order appears to be unravelling.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Can Liberal Foreign Policy Survive a Politics of Fear?
item.itunes:summary: In an ever-changing and uncertain global landscape, Nick Clegg outlines a set of reforms needed to safeguard the open international order against the forces of identity politics, nationalization and ‘strong man’ politics.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: The Arab Youth Survey: Voices of a Generation
item.itunes:summary: The Arab Youth Survey offers a unique insight into the attitudes and opinions of young people living in 16 Arab states, including the GCC countries and the Levant. Our panel discuss the findings of the most recent survey and assess its impacts.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Kenya Elections 2017: Prospects for a Credible Process
item.itunes:summary: Solomon Mugera and Dr Gabrielle Lynch discuss the prospects for a peaceful and credible election process with particular reference to the role of the media and the impact of devolution.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Contentious Borders: The Middle East and North Africa Post-2011
item.itunes:summary: In conjunction with the launch of the special issue of International Affairs, ‘Contentious borders: the Middle East and North Africa post-2011’, the contributors discuss resilient and changing territorial borders in the MENA region post-2011.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Chatham House Debate: Does 'Fake News' Matter?
item.itunes:summary: Chatham House presents four distinguished panellists who will debate the proposition ‘does fake news matter?’ Is it an overblown concept of little import? Or does the concept have important consequences?
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Angola Forum 2017: Economic Diversification, Development and Strengthening Democracy
item.itunes:summary: The Angola Forum 2017 brought together government, opposition, civil society and businesses to examine Angola’s economic and political future post-election.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Angola Forum 2017: Economic Diversification, Development and Strengthening Democracy
item.itunes:summary: The Angola Forum 2017 brought together government, opposition, civil society and businesses to examine Angola’s economic and political future post-election.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Marking Fifty Years Since the Six-Day War: What Next for Israel and Palestine?
item.itunes:summary: 5 June 2017 marks the 50 year anniversary of the Six-Day War. Itamar Rabinovich, author of Yitzhak Rabin’s biography, discusses the lasting impact the war continues to have on the region.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Yemen’s Political Wildcard
item.itunes:summary: This event will dicuss the chaos following the ousting of Ali Abdullah Saleh in 2011 from the presidency of Yemen and the civil war and regional interference that have plagued the Arab world’s poorest country since.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Iran’s Presidential Elections: A Game Changer for the Region?
item.itunes:summary: This event discusses Iran’s presidential elections in May which will determine whether President Hassan Rouhani may seek a second, four-year term and push ahead with reforms resisted by powerful hardliners.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Global Wine Markets and Brexit
item.itunes:summary: At this event, Professor Kym Anderson, a world authority on the wine market, presents the impacts of Brexit on bilateral wine trade values and volumes for commercial and fine still wines as well as for sparkling wines.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Post-Election Political and Security Dynamics on the Korean Peninsula
item.itunes:summary: Our panel offer an early analysis of election results in South Korea, assess the winning candidate Moon Jae-in’s campaign and what this will mean for South Korea going forward.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Sexual Violence in Conflict
item.itunes:summary: Our panel discuss local and international efforts to prevent and respond to sexual and gender-based violence.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: The African Union Vision for Peace and Prosperity in Africa
item.itunes:summary: H.E. Moussa Faki Mahamat discusses the AU’s current approach to challenges, how it ensures effective implementation of democracy, elections and human rights, and the commitment of member states to their obligations
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Outlining Labour's Defence and Foreign Policy Priorities
item.itunes:summary: The leader of the Labour Party outlined the key national security and foreign policy positions upon which his party is contesting the UK general election in June.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: The Role of the V4 in the Future of the EU
item.itunes:summary: This event asks the European affairs ministers from each Visegrád nation to outline their hopes for the future for the EU and their wish to see the shifting state of the EU as an opportunity rather than a threat for their country.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Prospects for Peace and Stability in the Middle East
item.itunes:summary: Ahmed Aboul Gheit, secretary-general of the League of Arab States, discusses the challenges confronting decision-makers in the Middle East.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Conflict in the Middle East: The Rising Influence of Sectarianism
item.itunes:summary: The panellists, using various case studies including Syria, Iraq, Lebanon and Saudi Arabia, examine the dynamics of sectarian violence in the Middle East.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: French Presidential Election Result: What Next for France and Europe
item.itunes:summary: Chatham House invited four experts to share their immediate reactions to the results.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: The Growth in Female Extremism: A Consequence of the Caliphate?
item.itunes:summary: The panel discuss the rise of female involvement in extremism and, in particular, their crucial role in online recruitment of both men and women through evolving social media channels.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: International Affairs 93:2 – Political Prediction in an Age of Uncertainty
item.itunes:summary: In this podcast, Nigel Gould-Davies discusses his recent review article on the difficulties of political forecasting. In an age of declining trust in experts and pollsters, how can prediction be done better?
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Diplomacy and Executive Power: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly
item.itunes:summary: This event drew on real life examples to explore instances of both successful and failed diplomacy.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Chatham House Primer: The Vote for Brexit
item.itunes:summary: Drawing on survey evidence collected over more than a decade, Matthew Goodwin explains why a majority of British voters decided to ignore much of the national and international community and vote for Brexit.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: From Conflict to Democracy: Can Elections Instigate Peace?
item.itunes:summary: Drawing on the findings of their recent research, Dr Annette Fath-Lihic and Professor Attahiru Muhammadu Jega discuss the dynamics around the question of the timing of transitional elections.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Freedom of the Media: Censorship, Imprisonment and Torture
item.itunes:summary: This event takes a look at the role of independent journalism and how it plays a vital role in bringing injustices, human rights abuses and corruption to the global public consciousness.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Should the UK Welcome More Child Refugees?
item.itunes:summary: At this event, Alfred Dubs argues that European countries have a moral duty to take in unaccompanied child refugees and urges the UK government to honour the terms of the Dubs Amendment of 2016.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Screening Room: Lost in Lebanon
item.itunes:summary: Following six years of civil war in Syria, some 13 million Syrians are estimated to have fled the country and roughly 1.5 million of these have found a temporary home in neighbouring Lebanon. The panel discuss the themes raised by the film.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Chatham House Debate: Are We Entering the Post-West World Order?
item.itunes:summary: This event asks four distinguished speakers to debate the proposition that the world is moving away from the traditional, European and US-led, liberal international order.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: The UK and Africa in the International System: Priorities and Engagement Post-Brexit
item.itunes:summary: This event brought together academics, business representatives, diplomats and government representatives, relevant stakeholders from across Whitehall departments and other experts to discuss what the UK’s vision for post-Brexit Africa will be.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Asfari Forum: Perspectives on Islam and Democracy
item.itunes:summary: The annual Asfari Forum, jointly hosted by Chatham House and the Asfari Foundation, convenes experts, policymakers and civil society practitioners to encourage better understanding and dialogue with key issues related to the Middle East region.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: The Case for Foreign Aid
item.itunes:summary: Kate Osamor sets out a strong defence of aid and its role in bolstering both the UK’s reputation and influence abroad.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: The Battle for Ukraine: Leadership and Solidarity
item.itunes:summary: President Poroshenko outlines the challenges ahead and offers his views on what kind of leadership is needed, how to consolidate solidarity, restore peace, reinforce wider European security and sustain the transformation of Ukraine.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Can Political Criminality Coexist With Democracy?
item.itunes:summary: The nexus between crime and politics raises complex questions. Using the world’s largest democracy, India, as a case study, this event explores if free and fair elections can indeed coexist with criminality.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Evolution of the Horn of Africa: State Formation and Decay
item.itunes:summary: In this podcast, Christopher Clapham speaks to Ahmed Soliman to discuss what distinguishes the Horn of Africa from the rest of the continent as assessed in his latest book The Horn of Africa: State Formation and Decay.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Media, Democracy and Political Influence: Does the Fourth Estate Still Matter?
item.itunes:summary: The panellists consider the role of contemporary media against the backdrop of the rise of new media and the supposed decline of print, the growth of citizen journalism and claims that journalistic standards are slipping amidst so called 'fake news'.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Assessing the Reality of a US-UK Trade Deal
item.itunes:summary: Laura Lane discusses the possibility of a bilateral trade deal between the two countries and question if the UK needs to negotiate a new trade and investment agreement with Europe before committing to an American economic alliance.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: The Nuclear Education of Donald Trump
item.itunes:summary: At this event, Dr Williams and her fellow panellists forecast potential nuclear policies that may be implemented during the Trump administration.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Women and Work: A View from the World
item.itunes:summary: This event discusses the findings of the joint International Labour Organization and Gallup report Towards a Better Future for Women and Work: Voices of Women and Men.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Should a Government Spy on its Citizens?
item.itunes:summary: Rhodri Jeffreys-Jones makes the case that governments have a moral duty to spy on their citizens in the interests of national security and the harm that state surveillance currently inflicts on civil liberties has been exaggerated.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: China’s Changing Approach to International Law
item.itunes:summary: In this podcast, Bill Hayton, Rod Wye and Wim Muller take a look at China's increasing engagement with international law.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula: From Global Insurgent to State Enforcer?
item.itunes:summary: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) is regularly cited as one of the most dangerous of the Al Qaeda franchises. Our panel discuss the need for a shift in how AQAP is considered by the international community.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: What Next For Britain?
item.itunes:summary: With the UK government poised to trigger Article 50, Keir Starmer, the shadow secretary of state for exiting the European Union, outlined the Labour Party’s guiding principles and priorities for the coming negotiations with the EU.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Ebola: The Epidemic of Fear?
item.itunes:summary: The unprecedented Ebola epidemic in Liberia, Sierra Leone, and Guinea in 2014-15 caught the world off-guard. This event seeks to unpack how far these reactions were based on fear rather than on sound medical practice.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Growth in Africa: The End of Africa Rising?
item.itunes:summary: At this event, director of the IMF’s Africa department, Abebe Selassie discusses Africa’s current economic trajectory, highlighting the necessary fiscal and policy responses to ensure inclusive and sustainable recovery.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Unheard Voices: Stories of Hope and Inspiration from the Middle East
item.itunes:summary: Based on their extensive experiences in the fields of education, culture, health, female empowerment and social enterprise, the panel provide insights into their work in the Middle East.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: China and the Future of the International Legal Order
item.itunes:summary: In this podcast, Bill Hayton, Kerry Brown and Katherine Morton take a look at China and the future of the international legal order.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Chatham House Primer: The Future of Work
item.itunes:summary: Richard and Daniel Susskind outline the main challenges that new technologies will pose for our existing conceptions of education, career and retirement.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Annexed Crimea: Crimean Tatars and their Struggle for Freedom
item.itunes:summary: The panel discuss the realities of annexation and the role of Crimean Tatars in resisting the occupation, and suggest how the West can better support the Crimean Tatars.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: What Are the Constitutional Consequences of Brexit?
item.itunes:summary: This event brings together legal and political experts to analyse the logistics of triggering Article 50 and the potential constitutional consequences of doing so.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: The Future of Women, Empowerment and Tolerance in Gulf Societies
item.itunes:summary: Dr al-Qubaisi addresses the UAE’s efforts to create a cohesive and empowered society through the principles outlined in Vision 2021. What could nations in the Arab world be doing to promote acceptance and empowerment within their borders?
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Six Years on from the Arab Spring: What Space is there for Dissent?
item.itunes:summary: This Chatham House event brings together four voices from across the region to discuss the personal and political fallout of the Arab uprising.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Chatham House Primer: The French Presidential Election
item.itunes:summary: Professor John Gaffney outlines the importance of an election held against the background of distrust of the establishment, corruption scandals, growing Euroscepticism and the increasing threat of terrorism.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: John Major at Chatham House on the Realities of Brexit for Britain and Europe
item.itunes:summary: In his first public speech since the EU referendum, Sir John Major outlined the realities that he believes both Britain and Europe face in the future at Chatham House.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: The Truman Doctrine at 70
item.itunes:summary: Drawing on first hand reflections from a divisive presidential campaign, Hillary Clinton’s running mate, Senator Tim Kaine, discusses the Truman Doctrine and America's role in a changing world.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: The Renminbi: A New Global Currency?
item.itunes:summary: Our panel look back at the development of China’s currency, unpack its reliance on the dollar and consider how China is approaching the challenge of building a global currency whilst trying to keep economic stability.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Brexit: The Reality Principle and the Pleasure Principle
item.itunes:summary: Herman Van Rompuy offers his thoughts on the future of the European Union without the United Kingdom.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Screening Room: The Journey to Europe
item.itunes:summary: At this event, the speakers discuss the desperate plight of sub-Saharan migrants who are routinely subjected to torture, kidnap and sexual abuse throughout their arduous journeys to Europe.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Twilight of the Liberal World Order?
item.itunes:summary: Robert Kagan argues that President Trump has thus far shown little interest in preserving the liberal world order.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: The Future for Women in Saudi Arabia
item.itunes:summary: This panel investigates the future for women in Saudi Arabia. How will women’s participation in the workforce increase if women are increasingly finding more opportunities abroad?
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Can Governments Encourage Entrepreneurship?
item.itunes:summary: This event focused on how governments, both independently and in partnership with the private sector, can encourage entrepreneurship to ensure that the entrepreneurial environment is inclusive and empowering.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Disunited Kingdom: Devolution, Deals and Brexit
item.itunes:summary: This event discusses the challenges Brexit raises for the devolved administrations: the panellists analyse how leaving the EU will affect each country’s external relations, internal workings and relationships.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: International Affairs 93:1 - India's Rise at 70
item.itunes:summary: In this podcast we hear highlights from our recent launch event at Chatham House, as well as interviews with two contributors, Amrita Narlikar and Harsh V. Pant, on their areas of expertise.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Bombing Yemen: Tracking an Airstrike from Manufacture to Impact
item.itunes:summary: The war in Yemen has been raging since 2015. Following a screening, the filmmaker is joined onstage by other panellists to discuss the conflict in Yemen and the use of UK- and US-supplied weapons in Saudi-led airstrikes.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Security and Defence in South Asia
item.itunes:summary: Relations between Afghanistan, Pakistan and India have long been fraught with complications. This event focuses on current thinking in each of these three countries towards their neighbours.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Japan and the World: Episode 6
item.itunes:summary: In this podcast, Dr John Nilsson-Wright sits down with Professor Richard Samuels.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Priorities for the New UN Secretary General
item.itunes:summary: This event looks back over the UN’s global involvement in 2016 and discusses whether current priorities will significantly change under a new secretary general.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: How Secure is Eastern Europe?
item.itunes:summary: In a bid to bolster the defence of its eastern flank, NATO has stationed thousands of troops, armour and aircraft in Poland and the Baltic states. This panel assesses these military manoeuvres.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: 10 Crises to Watch in 2017
item.itunes:summary: After another turbulent year for global peace and security, Lord Malloch-Brown and Jonathan Prentice examine what International Crisis Group considers to be the ten conflicts to watch in 2017.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Brexit and Beyond: Europe’s Last Chance?
item.itunes:summary: Guy Verhofstadt – the European Parliament’s chief negotiator for Brexit and former prime minister of Belgium – sets out his vision for the future of the political order in Europe.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Leaders Who Lunch: Robin Niblett on Effective Leadership
item.itunes:summary: The ‘Leaders who Lunch’ series gives Academy fellows the opportunity to discuss leadership experiences and lessons in an informal setting.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: The End of the Asian Century?
item.itunes:summary: At this event, the panel discuss the proposition that we could be witnessing the end of the “Asian Century”.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Decision Time: Who Will Be the Next Leader of the World Health Organization?
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: The Global Challenge of Ending FGM
item.itunes:summary: This event begins with a screening of Omnia: a short documentary of a young woman’s experience of undergoing FGM. The panellists then discuss the film before focusing on the cultural and health reasons for ending FGM.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: How Terrorism is Funded

item.itunes:summary: Two years into his post, the foreign minister of Sri Lanka outlines the reconciliation efforts brought in by President Maithripala Sirisena following the end of 25 years of conflict in the country.

item.itunes:summary: In this podcast, John Nilsson-Wright speaks with an expert panel about the rise of populism, Japanese reactions to Brexit and the Trump effect on international trade and the Trans-Pacific Partnership.

item.itunes:summary: In this podcast, Ambassador Reuben E. Brigety II speaks to Xenia Wickett about the challenge for American soft power following the 2016 US presidential election and its role in a changing international system.

item.itunes:summary: This event, in collaboration with the Daiwa Anglo-Japanese Foundation, looked beyond the UK's relationship with China to assess the impact of Brexit on some other key trading partners in Asia.

item.itunes:summary: The Asia Foundation present findings from a comprehensive perceptions poll covering all 34 provinces.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.itunes:summary: The campaign to take back ISIS’s stronghold in Syria, Raqqa, has started and the battle in Aleppo has intensified. The panel examine how those two battles are playing out in Syria and the long term consequences of these conflicts.

item.title: Life After the Fall of the Soviet Union: Assessing the Future of the Region
item.itunes:summary: 2016 marks 25 years since the fall of the Soviet Union and the beginning of independence for former USSR states. To mark this anniversary, the panel reflects on the transition of the Soviet states to becoming independent countries.

item.title: International Affairs 92:6 – Brexit Reflections, Europe-Russia Relations
item.itunes:summary: This latest podcast features authors from the recent November issue of International Affairs.

item.title: Death of the White Paper: Can Fiction and Art Inform Foresight in International Security?
item.itunes:summary: August Cole argues that if surprises are the new normal, creative insights into these trends can provide a critical predictive tool.

item.title: Assessing the Future of the Kurdistan Regional Government
item.itunes:summary: HE Qubad Talabani, the deputy prime minister of the Kurdistan Regional Government responds to the effects of the demographic change within Iraqi Kurdistan and outlines both the Kurdish and international role in Mosul.

item.title: Plenary Session Three: The Future of the Transatlantic Relationship
item.itunes:summary: What will be the future of Europe’s relationship with the United States under the leadership of the newly elected president?
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Plenary Session Four: Europe Towards 2030
item.itunes:summary: What will Europe look like in 2030? Will it, as some headlines would suggest, descend into increasing chaos? Or can a different, more positive vision prevail?
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Boris Johnson on UK Foreign Policy in the Era of Brexit
item.itunes:summary: Boris Johnson argues that after the vote to leave the EU, Britain has the chance to define and establish a new forward-looking approach to its foreign policy.

item.title: Plenary Session One: The State of The Union: Europe in Crisis
item.itunes:summary: Brexit; a fragile currency; a refugee crisis; a stagnant economy; rising populism. Europe has a history of advancing through crisis. Can it do so again?
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Keynote Conversation: Digital Transformation: Adapt or Die?
item.itunes:summary: Does digital transformation represent a disruptive threat or an opportunity for growth in Europe?
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Plenary Session Two: Europe and China: Peril and Promise
item.itunes:summary: What does the future hold for the relationship between Europe and China?
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: US Election 2016: In Conversation with Bruce Stokes
item.itunes:summary: In this podcast, Jacob Parakilas speaks to Bruce Stokes about the mood of the American electorate following Donald Trump's victory in the 2016 US presidential election and what that means for US politics.

item.title: Has Brexit Pushed Europe Away from the Political Centre Ground?
item.itunes:summary: Our panellists analyse the Brexit vote and national sentiment towards the EU in other member states before considering the role far-right and far-left narratives played in the UK’s EU referendum.

item.title: In Conversation with Ambassador Barzun
item.itunes:summary: As Ambassador Matthew Barzun’s tenure in the UK comes to the end he will reflect on both where things currently stand for US-UK relations and what the future might hold.

item.title: New Developments in Turkish Domestic and Foreign Policy
item.itunes:summary: At this event, the Turkish deputy prime minister argued that all countries are facing similar, significant challenges since the current world order is not powerful nor convincing enough to prevent conflicts and unrest.

item.title: How Should Global Catastrophic Risks be Managed?
item.itunes:summary: This event discussed innovative ways in which the international community might tackle catastrophic risks to civilisation such as climate change, food & water security, nuclear war, bio-terrorism, disease, epidemic and antimicrobial resistance.

item.itunes:summary: The panel discussed how US president-elect might look to deliver on different policies in collaboration - or conflict - with a Republican House and Senate and a Democratic Party fiercely opposed to his election.

item.itunes:summary: Following on from the Conservative Party Conference, where the UK prime minister said that she plans to trigger Article 50 before March next year, the panel discussed how the Brexit negotiations are likely to play out.

item.itunes:summary: The Global Commission on Internet Governance recently launched its report One Internet. At this event, a selection of the commissioners, along with the chair of the commission, Carl Bildt, discussed the findings and recommendations of the report.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: US Election 2016: In Conversation with Miriam Sapiro
item.itunes:summary: In the latest US Election 2016 podcast – the first since Donald Trump won the US presidential election – Marianne Schneider-Petsinger and Miriam Sapiro look ahead to what we can expect from the Trump administration particularly on US trade policy.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Assessing North Korea’s Nuclear Capabilities
item.itunes:summary: North Korea has recently conducted its fifth nuclear test and is now thought to have a stockpile of around 20 devices. Our panel analysed whether the latest nuclear test is a game changer.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Yemen: Mapping the Way Forward
item.itunes:summary: The former vice-president and prime minister of Yemen discussed the situation on the ground and outlined approaches for peace-building in the country.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: US Election 2016: Economic Lessons for the Next Administration
item.itunes:summary: In the last of a three-part series on the US presidential election, this event unpacked the lessons for post-election economic management in the US.

item.itunes:summary: This event analysed the US presidential election, looking back over the election campaigns of the two major party nominees and looking ahead to what we can expect from the new Trump administration.

item.itunes:summary: This year's Martin Wight Memorial Lecture addressed the evolution of inequalities in the global economy and how different powers are propelling new forms of unequal development across the world.

item.title: Refuge from Conflict: Citizenship and Forced Migration in East and Central Africa
item.itunes:summary: At this event, Dr Hovil discussed how refugees challenge the parameters of citizenship as they carve out spaces for inclusion, and how policy environments can overcome marginalization of victims of forced migration.

item.itunes:summary: At this meeting, Walter Mzembi, minister of tourism and hospitality industry of Zimbabwe, discussed how tourism needs to be managed by the public and private sectors together towards a more transformative effect for African economies.

item.itunes:summary: At this event, Charlotte Osei reflected on the significance and process of electoral reforms, and discussed the Electoral Commission of Ghana's ambitions, challenges and approach ahead of the December polls.

item.itunes:summary: Upon the publication of his autobiography, Out of the Desert, Al-Naimi discussed lessons learned from his time in office and offers some reflections on changing global energy markets and Saudi Arabia’s role therein.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: The Future Shape of US Trade Policy
item.itunes:summary: In the run-up to the US election, the panel considered what lies ahead for US trade policy and what this could mean for the global economy.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: How ‘European’ is European Philosophy?
item.itunes:summary: This brief lecture focussed on two cultures, those of ancient India and the Islamic world, and how these relate to European philosophy in very different ways.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Japan and the World: Episode 5
item.itunes:summary: In this podcast, Izumi Nakamitsu talks to John Nilsson-Wright about the role of the United Nations as a global peacekeeping organization.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: International Affairs 92.5: Global Health Crises and the Paris Climate Change Agreement
item.itunes:summary: In the September 2016 issue of International Affairs, a wide range of topics were covered, from cybersecurity to Angolan politics. This podcast features interviews with three of the authors from the issue.

item.title: US Election 2016: The Future of the US Supreme Court
item.itunes:summary: In this podcast, Xenia Wickett and James D. Zirin discuss the US Supreme Court, how it fits into the US system and how it could affect the next president.

item.itunes:summary: In his new book, Foreign Policy: Thinking Outside the Box, Amitai Etzioni sets out his thinking on foreign policy. At this event, Professor Etzioni discusses his theories, while other members of the panel challenge his ideas.

item.itunes:summary: The panel looks beyond the battle, to consider the political actors and arrangements that will likely emerge in a post-ISIS Mosul and question whether the leadership will be able to avoid factional tensions that could arise.

item.itunes:summary: A few weeks before a presidential election that may determine the makeup of the US Supreme Court justices for decades to come, lawyer, broadcaster and author James Zirin provides an overview of the constitutional importance of the highest court.

item.itunes:summary: This panel examines how these global jihadist narratives have evolved dramatically in the last five years. Panellists consider thematic changes inside the Middle East and North Africa, as well as in Europe and beyond.

item.itunes:summary: In the second of a three-part series on the US presidential election, this event analyses how the US election discourse is playing out on the global stage.

item.itunes:summary: This event, held in partnership with the Thomson Reuters Foundation, discusses what companies are doing to monitor and support their supply chains.

item.itunes:summary: The United Kingdom will face a number of challenges over the coming year. Chatham House, Citi and Clifford Chance hosted an event at the 2016 UK Labour Party conference to discuss the pressing issues.

item.itunes:summary: Dr Jacob Parakilas, assistant head of the US and the Americas Programme at Chatham House, and Ed Luce discuss the global implications of the 2016 US presidential race - a topic which Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton have displayed differing opinions on.

item.itunes:summary: In the first of a three-part series on the US election, this event analyzed the primary policy battlegrounds which are being contested by Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton.

item.itunes:summary: This event screened the entire film before a holding Q&A focused on its making, the work of the Syrian Civil Defense and the recent campaign to have the group nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize.

item.itunes:summary: At this event, the special representative of the secretary-general for Somalia, Michael Keating, discussed the political and security context ahead of the elections and UNSOM’s coordinating role.

item.itunes:summary: This event, which launched the UK Trade Policy Observatory initiative, analysed the WTO-related issues raised by the UK taking up its new status as an individual member without the responsibilities of an EU member.

item.itunes:summary: At this event, the panel reflected on the inquiry’s findings, considered the UK’s role in the war and the long term consequences of the conflict.

item.itunes:summary: At this meeting Zimbabwe's minister of finance and economic development, Hon Patrick Chinamasa, discussed the government's economic agenda and how it seeks to build the trust and confidence needed to succeed.

item.itunes:summary: At this event, the speakers discussed the domestic and regional implications of the economic crisis in South Sudan.

item.itunes:summary: At this event Mmusi Maimane, leader of the DA, discussed his perspectives on critical governance challenges and his party’s strategies for improving economic prospects and further consolidating democracy.

item.itunes:summary: Drawing on his recent publication, Mission Failure: America and the World in the Post-Cold War Era, Professor Mandelbaum examines international factors influencing the ongoing presidential campaign.

item.itunes:summary: In this event, Shiraz Maher demystifyed some of the core issues surrounding Salafi-jihadism, and also explained the intricacies within a broad and diverse religious tradition that is often caricatured in the media.

item.itunes:summary: The latest episode of our podcast series looks at the effects of a Leave vote on UK diplomatic strategy, defence procurement and Britain's relationship with France, with two authors from the latest issue of International Affairs.

item.title: Event Speech: Israel and Gaza: The Children of War
item.itunes:summary: Children in Gaza and across the border in Israel have lived through three wars in six years. Last summer more than 500 children were killed in a 51-day war, all but one of them Palestinian. Almost every child in Gaza lost a loved one. On the Israeli border children lived in constant fear of rocket attacks and underground tunnels.

item.title: Event Speech: Tackling Humanitarian Crises in Time: Lessons from the West Africa Ebola Responses

item.title: Event Speech: More Police or More Doctors? How to Best Tackle Illicit Drugs
item.itunes:summary: In 1971, President Richard Nixon declared the beginning of the US-led war on drugs. Over forty years later, the illegal narcotics trade is worth an estimated $332 billion, costs law enforcement an estimated $100 billion per annum and has seen an increase in users worldwide from 203 million in 2008 to 243 million in 2012. Is the war on drugs failing?
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Event Speech: Combating Ebola in Liberia: The Role of The International Community
item.itunes:summary: Since the start of the West African Ebola outbreak in March 2014, the disease has claimed over 2,400 lives in Liberia alone, representing around half of the total casualties across the four countries with reported cases. The inability to effectively control the outbreak has in part been due to systemic weaknesses and capacity limitations.
item.itunes:author: Chatham House

item.title: Session 1: Explaining the emergence of Sovereign Wealth Funds in Africa
item.itunes:summary: This conference considers how SWFs can develop strategies to ensure their performance as accountable financial tools in service of national economies, rather than becoming grey financial tools or parallel budgets.
